Does there exist an absolute constant $c>0$ such that, for all $r\geq 2$, in any $r$-uniform hypergraph with chromatic number $3$ there is a vertex contained in at least $(1+c)^r$ many edges?



In general, determine the largest integer $f(r)$ such that every $r$-uniform hypergraph with chromatic number $3$ has a vertex contained in at least $f(r)$ many edges. It is easy to see that $f(2)=2$ and $f(3)=3$. Erd\H{o}s did not know the value of $f(4)$.

This was solved by Erd\H{o}s and Lov\'{a}sz \cite{ErLo75}, who proved in particular that there is a vertex contained in at least\[\frac{2^{r-1}}{4r}\]many edges.




References


[ErLo75] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Lov\'{a}sz, L., Problems and results on {$3$}-chromatic hypergraphs and some
related questions. (1975), 609--627.
